column1: Scale Invariant Fully Convolutional Network: Detecting Hands Efficiently
Dan Liu@University of Chinese Academy of Sciences
column4: Libo Zhang@Institute of Software Chinese Academy of Sciences
column5: Tiejian Luo@University of Chinese Academy of Sciences

column1: Existing hand detection methods usually follow the pipeline of multiple stages with high computation cost
column6: and additional layers for rotated region detection. In this paper
column7: we propose a new Scale Invariant Fully Convolutional Network (SIFCN) trained in an end-to-end fashion to detect hands efficiently. Specifically
column8: we merge the feature maps from high to low layers in an iterative way
column9: which handles different scales of hands better with less time overhead comparing to concatenating them simply. Moreover
column10: we develop the Complementary Weighted Fusion (CWF) block to make full use of the distinctive features among multiple layers to achieve scale invariance. To deal with rotated hand detection
column11: we present the rotation map to get rid of complex rotation and derotation layers. Besides
column12: we design the multi-scale loss scheme to accelerate the training process significantly by adding supervision to the intermediate layers of the network. Compared with the state-of-the-art methods
column13: our algorithm shows comparable accuracy and runs a 4.23 times faster speed on the VIVA dataset and achieves better average precision on Oxford hand detection dataset at a speed of 62.5 fps.
